Tesla's current products include [[electric car]]s, battery [[energy storage]] from home to grid scale, solar panels and solar roof tiles, as well as other related products and services. Founded in July 2003 as Tesla Motors, the company's name is a tribute to inventor and electrical engineer [[Nikola Tesla]]. [[Elon Musk]], who contributed most of the funding in the early days, has served as CEO since 2008. According to Musk, the purpose of Tesla is to help expedite the move to sustainable transport and energy, obtained through electric vehicles and solar power.{{Cite web |title=Revisiting "The Secret Tesla Motors Master Plan (just between you and me)" |url=https://insideevs.com/news/318223/revisiting-the-secret-tesla-motors-master-plan-just-between-you-and-me/ |access-date=August 31, 2020 |website=InsideEVs |language=en}} Tesla ranked as the world's best-selling [[Plug-in electric vehicle|plug-in]] and [[Battery electric vehicle|battery electric]] passenger car manufacturer in 2019, with a market share of 17% of the plug-in segment and 23% of the battery electric segment. Tesla global vehicle sales were 499,550 units in 2020, a 35.8% increase over the previous year.{{cite web |title=Tesla Q4 2020 Vehicle Production & Deliveries |url=https://ir.tesla.com/press-release/tesla-q4-2020-vehicle-production-deliveries |website=tesla.com |access-date=January 2, 2021}} In 2020, the company surpassed the 1 million mark of electric cars produced. The [[Tesla Model 3|Model 3]] ranks as the world's all-time best-selling plug-in electric car, with more than 500,000 delivered. Through its subsidiary [[SolarCity]], Tesla develops and is a major installer of [[Photovoltaic system|solar photovoltaic]] systems in the United States. Tesla is also one of the largest global suppliers of battery energy storage systems, from home-scale to grid-scale. Tesla installed some of the largest battery storage plants in the world and supplied 1.65 GWh of battery storage in 2019. Tesla has been the subject of numerous lawsuits and controversies, arising from the statements and the conduct of CEO Elon Musk, allegations of whistleblower retaliation, alleged worker rights violations, and allegedly unresolved and dangerous technical problems with their products. {{TOC limit|3}} == History == [[File:Tesla Roadster Sport insignia.jpg|thumb|upright|The insignia of Tesla Motors as seen on a [[Tesla Roadster Sport]] ]] {{Main|History of Tesla, Inc.}} ===2003–2004: Founding=== Founded as ''Tesla Motors'', Tesla was incorporated on July 1, 2003, by [[Martin Eberhard]] and [[Marc Tarpenning]].{{Cite book |last=Vance |first=Ashlee |title=Elon Musk : Tesla, SpaceX, and the quest for a fantastic future |date=May 19, 2015 |isbn=978-0-06-230123-9 |edition=First |location=New York, NY |pages=151–155 |oclc=881436803 |quote="On July 1, 2003, Eberhard and Tarpenning incorporated their new company. " "The third desk was occupied a few months later by Ian Wright..." "...the three men went hunting for some venture capital funding in January 2004." "With an investment of $6.5 million, Musk had become the largest shareholder of Tesla and the chairman of the company." "Straubel stopped by the office for a meeting, and was hired right away in May 2004..."}} The two founders were influenced to start the company after [[General Motors|GM]] recalled all its [[General Motors EV1|EV1]] electric cars in 2003 and then destroyed them,{{Cite web |title=Elon Musk on Twitter |url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/873116351316938753 |access-date=June 9, 2017}} and seeing the [[Fuel efficiency|higher efficiency]] of battery-electric cars as an opportunity to break the usual correlation between high performance and low mileage.{{Cite web |date=September 24, 2007 |title=The 21st Century Electric Car |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/display_data/twentyfirstcenturycar.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071203085411/http://www.teslamotors.com/display_data/twentyfirstcenturycar.pdf |archive-date=December 3, 2007 |pages=6–8 |quote=the better the performance, the worse the mileage. But there is one car that is way off the curve: the Tesla Roadster. This car is clearly based on a disruptive technology – it simultaneously offers great acceleration and high energy efficiency.}} The [[AC Propulsion tzero]] also inspired the company's first vehicle, the [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|Roadster]].{{Cite web |last=Musk |first=Elon |date=December 9, 2018 |title=Major credit to AC Propulsion for the tzero electric sports car 1997-2003 that inspired Tesla Roadster. Without that, Tesla wouldn't exist or would have started much later.pic.twitter.com/NxCgYO9JXx |url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1071840664562786304 |access-date=December 9, 2018 |website=@elonmusk |language=en}}{{Cite web |last=Musk |first=Elon |date=May 31, 2016 |title=Elon Musk recounts Tesla's history at 2016 shareholders meeting (2016.5.31) |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AKfiKvbqbQw?t=765 |access-date=July 31, 2019 |website=youtube.com}} Eberhard said he wanted to build "a car manufacturer that is also a technology company", with its core technologies as "the battery, the computer software, and the proprietary motor".{{Cite news |date=July 30, 2007 |title=Tesla: A Carmaker With Silicon Valley Spark |language=en |work=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2007-07-29/tesla-a-carmaker-with-silicon-valley-spark |access-date=August 31, 2020}} Ian Wright was Tesla's third employee, joining a few months later. The three raised US$7.5 million in [[Series A round|Series A]] funding in February 2004, with Elon Musk contributing $6.5 million.{{Cite web |last=Burns |first=Matt |date=October 8, 2014 |title=A Brief History of Tesla |url=https://techcrunch.com/gallery/a-brief-history-of-tesla/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150717064829/https://techcrunch.com/gallery/a-brief-history-of-tesla/#/slide2 |archive-date=July 17, 2015 |access-date=June 11, 2015 |website=[[TechCrunch]] |quote="Tesla was founded not by Elon Musk, but rather by Martin Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning in July 2003. The two bootstrapped the fledgling auto company until [[Elon Musk]] led the company's US$7.5 million Series A financing round in February 2004."}}{{Cite web |title=Tesla Funding Rounds {{!}} Startup Ranking |url=https://www.startupranking.com/startup/tesla/funding-rounds |access-date=September 2, 2020 |website=StartupRanking |language=en-US}} Musk became chairman of the board of directors, and appointed Eberhard as CEO.{{Citation |title=Third Row Tesla Podcast – Elon's Story – Part 1 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NxmO_QuD4Do |language=en |access-date=April 17, 2020}} [[J. B. Straubel]] joined Tesla in May 2004. A lawsuit settlement agreed to by Eberhard and Tesla in September 2009 allows all five (Eberhard, Tarpenning, Wright, Musk and Straubel) to call themselves co-founders.{{Cite web |last=LaMonica |first=Martin |title=Tesla Motors founders: Now there are five |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/tesla-motors-founders-now-there-are-five/ |access-date=April 17, 2020 |website=CNET |language=en}} === 2005–2009: Roadster === {{Main|Tesla Roadster (first generation)}} Musk took an active role within the company and oversaw Roadster product design at a detailed level, but was not deeply involved in day-to-day business operations. From the beginning, Musk consistently maintained that Tesla's long-term strategic goal was to create affordable mass market electric vehicles.{{Cite web |date=September 17, 2008 |title=Elon Musk Envisions Tesla Electric Car as Low as $20K: Cleantech News |url=http://gigaom.com/cleantech/elon-musk-envisions-tesla-electric-car-as-low-as-20k/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150312185643/https://gigaom.com/2008/09/17/elon-musk-envisions-tesla-electric-car-as-low-as-20k/ |archive-date=March 12, 2015 |access-date=October 3, 2010 |publisher=Gigaom.com}} Tesla's goal was to start with a premium sports car aimed at early adopters and then moving into more mainstream vehicles, including sedans and affordable compacts.{{Cite web |last=Musk |first=Elon |date=August 2, 2006 |title=The Secret Tesla Motors Master Plan (just between you and me) No. 124 |url=http://www.tesla.com/blog/secret-tesla-motors-master-plan-just-between-you-and-me |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802142703/http://www.teslamotors.com/blog/secret-tesla-motors-master-plan-just-between-you-and-me |archive-date=August 2, 2010 |access-date=October 3, 2010|website=tesla.com |publisher=Tesla Motors}} {{Self-published source|inline|date=May 2015}} In February 2006, Musk led Tesla's [[Series B funding|Series B]] $13 million investment round which added Valor Equity Partners to the funding team.{{Cite web |title=Series B - Tesla - 2005-02-01 |url=https://www.crunchbase.com/funding_round/tesla-motors-series-b--ee3faaa9 |access-date=April 17, 2020 |website=Crunchbase |language=en}} Musk co-led the third, $40 million round in May 2006 along with Technology Partners. This round included investment from prominent entrepreneurs including [[Google]] co-founders [[Sergey Brin]] & [[Larry Page]], former [[eBay]] President [[Jeff Skoll]], [[Hyatt]] heir [[Nick Pritzker]] and added the VC firms [[Draper Fisher Jurvetson]], Capricorn Management, and The Bay Area Equity Fund managed by [[JPMorgan Chase]].{{Cite web |last=[[Martin Eberhard]] |date=August 7, 2007 |title=Martin Eberhard of Tesla Motors speaks to the Motor Press Guild |url=http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=-6124789175148491596 |access-date=June 22, 2008 |format=[[Flash video]]}} Musk led the fourth round in May 2008 which added another $40,167,530 in debt financing, and brought the total investments to over $100 million through private financing. {{side box|text= '''List of chief executive officers of Tesla''' 1 [[Martin Eberhard]] (2004–2007) 2 [[Ze'ev Drori]] (2007–2008) 3 [[Elon Musk]] (2008–present) }} Prototypes of the Tesla's first car, the Roadster, were officially revealed to the public on July 19, 2006, in [[Santa Monica, California]], at a 350-person invitation-only event held in Barker Hangar at Santa Monica Airport.{{Cite press release |title=Tesla Motors Hosts World Debut of Tesla Roadster Offering Performance, Style & Efficiency – With a Conscience |date=July 20, 2006 |publisher=Tesla Motors |url=http://www.teslamotors.com/media/press_room.php?id=42 |access-date=April 24, 2007}} Tesla began production of the Roadster in 2008.{{Cite web |last=Ramey |first=Jay |date=November 27, 2017 |title=The first Tesla Roadster: A look back at the early adopter's electric car |url=http://autoweek.com/news/green-cars/a1835876/first-tesla-roadster-look-back-early-adopters-electric-car/ |access-date=September 8, 2020 |website=Autoweek |language=en-US}} === 2010–2015: IPO, Model S and Model X === In January 2010 Tesla received a $465 million loan from the U.S. Department of Energy, which it repaid in 2013.{{Cite web |date=May 25, 2020 |title=TESLA |url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2012/06/22/tesla-motors-begins-delivering-model-s-electric-cars-in-a-silicon-valley-milestone-2/ |access-date=September 8, 2020 |website=The Mercury News |language=en-US}} and its first SUV, the [[Tesla Model X|Model X]], in September 2015.{{Cite web |last=Logan |first=Bryan |title=Here's Tesla's first SUV, the all-electric Model X $800 Million in Its First Week |first=Tom |last=Randall |agency=[[Bloomberg News]] |location=US |date=May 8, 2015 |access-date=October 13, 2016}} === 2016–present: SolarCity, Model 3, and Model Y === In November 2016, Tesla acquired SolarCity.{{Cite web |last=Cava |first=Marco della |title=Tesla shareholders approve deal to buy SolarCity |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/11/17/tesla-solarcity-deal-xxxx/94020994/ |access-date=September 14, 2020 |website=USA TODAY |language=en-US}} Few months later, in February 2017, Tesla Motors shortened its name to Tesla, Inc., to better reflect the scope of the expanded business. Tesla began selling the Model 3 sedan in July the same year.{{Cite web |title=Tesla hands over first Model 3 electric cars to early buyers |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/tesla-hands-over-first-model-3-electric-cars-early-buyers-n787716 |access-date=September 9, 2020 |website=NBC News |language=en}} Tesla also started its philanthropic effort. Tesla made multiple contributions of solar power to areas recovering from disasters in 2017.{{cite web|title=Tesla's Philanthropic Side|url=https://www.asaproofing.com/2017/10/tesla-philanthropic-side/|website=asaproofing.com}}{{cite web|title=Tesla Turns Power Back On At Children's Hospital In Puerto Rico|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/10/25/560045944/tesla-turns-power-back-on-at-childrens-hospital-in-puerto-rico|website=NPR.org}} In July 2018, the company donated $37.5 million to K-12 STEM education in Nevada.{{cite web|url=https://www.insidephilanthropy.com/home/2018/7/26/next-gen-whats-behind-teslas-latest-stem-education-give|title=Next Gen: What's Behind Tesla's Latest web|url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2018/08/07/elon-musk-tesla-private-tweet/|title=Elon Musk tweets he’s thinking about taking Tesla private}} In March 2020, Tesla began deliveries of the [[Tesla |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2020/03/17/model-y-deliveries-begin-heres-what-is-new-in-teslas-ev-crossover/ |access-date=September 9, 2020 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}} On January 10, |url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/unternehmen/industrie/e-autohersteller-tesla-ist-wertvoller-als-bmw-daimler-und-vw-zusammen/25905882.html |access-date=November 25, 2020 |website=www.handelsblatt.com |language=de}} The next month, Tesla reached a market capitalization of [[US$|$]]206 billion, surpassing [[Toyota]]'s $202 billion to become the world's most valuable automaker by market last|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/12/14/tesla-valuation-more-than-nine-largest-carmakers-combined-why.html|access-date=2021-01-07|website=CNBC|language=en}} It was announced in January 2021 that the Buss; CEO and Chairman of [[Johnson Publishing Company]] Linda Johnson Rice; and Daimler executive Herbert Kohler. == Business strategy == [[File:Tesla cars, price and production3.png|thumb|Tesla strategy of starting with low-volume high-priced cars and evolving to higher-volume lower-priced cars.]] Tesla's product release strategy is to emulate [[Consumer electronics#Trends|typical technological-product life cycles]] and initially target affluent buyers, and then move into larger markets at lower price points.{{Cite web |last=Robert Scardino |date=July 17, 2009 |title=MSNBC Calls EV Drivers 'Lunatic Fringe' |url=http://www.allcarselectric.com/blog/1022275_msnbc-calls-ev-drivers-lunatic-fringe |access-date=August 8, 2009 |publisher=AllCarsElectric.com}} The battery and electric drivetrain technology for each model are developed and partially paid for through the sales of earlier models.{{Cite news |last=Welch |first=David |date=July 30, 2007 |title=Tesla: A Carmaker With Silicon Valley Spark |publisher=BloombergBusinessweek |url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2007-07-29/tesla-a-carmaker-with-silicon-valley-spark |url-status=live |access-date=March 13, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140914195549/http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2007-07-29/tesla-a-carmaker-with-silicon-valley-spark |archive-date=September 14, 2014}} The Roadster was low-volume and priced at $109,000. Model S and Model X target the broader luxury market. Model 3 and the Model Y are aimed at a higher-volume segment.{{Cite news |last=Vaughan |first=Adam |date=October 25, 2013 |title=12 interesting things we learned from Tesla's Elon Musk this week |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=UK |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/oct/25/things-learned-tesla-elon-musk-electric-car |access-date=October 26, 2013}} This strategy is common in the technology industry.{{Cite web |date=July 14, 2009 |title=Abu Dhabi Joins Feds as Tesla Backer |url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/around-town/shopping/Abu-Dhabi-Joins-Feds-as-Tesla-Investor.html |access-date=August 8, 2009 |website=NBC Bay Area}} With the Model S, Tesla's technology strategy was to start with a "clean-sheet" design,{{Cite news |date=October 4, 2017 |title=German carmakers relying on volume to confront Tesla |language=de |work=Reuters |url=https://de.reuters.com/article/us-autos-electric-analysis-idUSKBN1C921T |access-date=September 1, 2020}} and build an integrated computer hardware and software architecture at the center of its vehicles. Doing so enables Tesla to provide online ("over-the-air") software updates to its cars,{{Cite news |last=Borroz |first=Tony |date=February 19, 2010 |title=Tesla CEO Honored for 'Enlightened Vision' |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |url=https://www.wired.com/autopia/2010/02/elon-musk-executive-of-the-year-innovator-award/ |access-date=April 12, 2015}}{{Cite news |last=Shipley |first=Lou |date=February 28, 2020 |title=How Tesla Sets Itself Apart |work=Harvard Business Review |url=https://hbr.org/2020/02/how-tesla-sets-itself-apart |access-date=September 5, 2020 |issn=0017-8012}} which allows Tesla to improve the functionality and performance of its already-sold cars for free. Tesla also continuously improve the hardware of its cars rather than waiting for a new model year, as opposed to nearly every other car manufacturer.{{Cite web|date=August 29, 2020|title=Tesla Introduced A Business Model The World Has Not Seen Before|url=https://cleantechnica.com/2020/08/29/tesla-introduced-a-business-model-the-world-has-not-seen-before/|access-date=September 1, 2020|website=CleanTechnica|language=en-US}} [[File:Tesla auto bots.jpg|thumb|[[industrial robot|Robotic]] manufacturing of the Model S at the [[Tesla Factory]] in [[Fremont, California]]]] Tesla does not advertise. The company aims to educate customers through its showrooms, and sells its vehicles online rather than through a conventional dealer network.{{Cite web|first=Richard|last= Read|title=GM Follows Tesla's Lead, Plans To Sell Directly To Online Shoppers|url=https://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1087492_gm-follows-teslas-lead-plans-to-sell-directly-to-online-shoppers|access-date=February 2, 2020|website=The Car Connection|language=en}}{{Cite web|title=7 Reasons Why Tesla Insists on Selling its Own Cars|url=https://fortune.com/2016/01/19/why-tesla-sells-directly/|access-date=September 1, 2020|website=Fortune|language=en}} Tesla has showrooms in malls and other high-traffic areas. Musk believes existing dealerships have a conflict of interest and will not promote electric cars from Tesla or any manufacturer,{{Cite web|date=October 22, 2012|title=Elon Musk speaks out about Tesla and franchise laws|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/blog/2012/10/elon-musk-speaks-out-about-tesla-and.html|access-date=September 1, 2020|website=www.bizjournals.com}} because they make more money servicing than selling cars, and electric cars have lower servicing costs.{{Cite web|title=Why you can't buy a Tesla in these states|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/cant-buy-tesla-states-161318245.html|access-date=September 1, 2020|website=finance.yahoo.com|language=en-US}} Tesla is the first automaker in the United States that sells cars directly to consumers; all others use independently owned dealerships.{{cite news|last=O'Toole|first=James|date=July 2, 2013|title=Tesla direct-sales petition hits 100,000 signatures|publisher=CNN|url=https://money.cnn.com/2013/07/02/autos/tesla-petition/|access-date=April 12, 2015}} [[File:The Tesla Patent Wall at HQ, now set free.jpg|thumb|left|The Tesla Patent Wall at its headquarters was removed after the company announced its patents are part of the [[Open-source-software movement|open source movement]].{{cite news |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/tesla-motors-opens-patents-elon-musks-electric-cars-now-part-open-source-movement-1600522 |title=Tesla Motors Opens Patents: Elon Musk's Electric Cars Now Part Of 'Open Source Movement' |author=Maria Gallucci |date=June 13, 2014 |newspaper=HybridCars.com |access-date=June 14, 2014}}]] Tesla has a high degree of [[vertical integration]], reaching 80% in 2016. In July 2020, Musk, relying on data obtained through their partnership with State National Insurance, announced that Tesla was creating its own major insurance company. The insurance will use individual vehicle date to offer personalized pricing.{{cite news|last=Sully|first=Evan|date=October 21, 2020|title=Experts say Tesla's unique data-tracking abilities give it an advantage as Elon Musk looks to build a 'major insurance company' for Tesla owners|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-vehicle-data-advantage-car-insurance-ambitions-elon-musk-analysts-2020-10|work=Business Insider|access-date=November 29, 2020}} On June 4, 2017, the [[American Automobile Association]] raised insurance rates for Tesla owners following a report from the [[Highway Loss Data Institute]]. Similarly, the Model X was concluded to crash 41% more often and to be 89% more expensive to repair than similar vehicles. As a result, AAA raised insurance rates on Tesla cars by 30%. Tesla said that the analysis is "severely flawed and not reflective of reality", however, Tesla failed to provide any contradictory numbers.{{cite web |url=http://www.leftlanenews.com/aaa-raising-insurance-costs-for-tesla-owners-96345.html |title=AAA raising insurance rates for Tesla owners |last=Glon |first=Ronan |date=June 4, 2017 |publisher=Left Lane News |access-date=June 7, 2017 }} Shortly thereafter, Russ Rader, the spokesman for the [[Insurance Institute for Highway Safety]], confirmed the AAA's analysis and that "Teslas get into a lot of crashes and are costly to repair afterward".{{cite news |url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20170604/FINANCE_AND_INSURANCE/170609884/-tesla-owners-should-pay-more-for-insurance-aaa-says |title=Tesla owners should pay more for insurance, AAA says |last=Burke |first=Katie |date=June 4, 2017 |newspaper=Automotive News |access-date=June 7, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://jalopnik.com/aaa-raises-insurance-rates-on-tesla-vehicles-1795814904 |title=AAA Raises Insurance Rates On Tesla Vehicles Because Repairs Are So Costly |last=Felton |first=Ryan |website=[[Jalopnik]] |date=June 5, 2017|access-date=June 7, 2017}} The following year, an analysis of claim frequency and insurance cost data by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety conducted by financial research provider 24/7 Wall St. found that the Tesla Model S and Model X were the two most expensive vehicles to insure. Evaluating Clean Air Act Compliance At Tesla Factory|url=https://www.thedrive.com/tech/28667/epa-join-local-authorities-in-evaluating-clean-air-act-compliance-at-tesla-factory|access-date=May 18, 2020|website=The Drive}} and fined Tesla for hazardous waste violations in April 2019.{{Cite web|last=O'Kane|first=Sean|date=April 1, 2019|title=Tesla penalized for violating hazardous waste law at fires ==== In June 2012, Tesla knew the battery cooling system in its Model S cars had a flawed design that made it susceptible to leaks, which could short the battery or cause a fire.{{Cite web|last=Lopez|first=Linette|title=Tesla knew its Model S battery had a design flaw that could lead to leaks and, ultimately, fires starting in 2012. It sold the car anyway.|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-faulty-battery-cooling-systems-design-model-s-2012-2019-6|access-date=June 24, 2020|website=Business Insider}} Tesla continued to sell Model S cars with this flawed cooling system through late 2012, even as employees found these parts leaking on the production line. In October 2019, the [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA) began investigating Tesla's Model S and X vehicles for potential battery defects that could cause "non-crash" fires.{{Cite web|last=Blanco|first=Sebastian|date=November 1, 2019|title=NHTSA, Investigating Tesla Fire Reports, Demands Data on Battery Software Changes|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a29666731/nhtsa-investigation-tesla-fire-reports/|access-date=June 24, 2020|website=Car and Driver|language=en-US}} ==== Giga New York ==== Tesla's [[Giga New York]] factory, which was built and equipped using nearly $1 billion in New York taxpayer money, has faced criticism and legal actions regarding allegations of inflated job promises, cost overruns, construction delays, [[bid rigging]], a perceived lack of effort from Musk, and claims that the deal was, in effect, a bailout of Musk's cousins Peter and Lyndon Rive.{{Cite news|url= https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/06/22/musk-calls-teslas-solarcity-deal-no-brainer-investors-disagree/86249516/ |title=Musk calls Tesla's SolarCity deal 'no-brainer'; investors disagree|work=USA TODAY|access-date=September 4, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://buffalonews.com/2019/07/24/teslas-solar-energy-business-takes-a-turn-for-the-worse/ |title=Tesla's solar energy business takes a turn for the worse |last=Robinson |first=David |date=July 24, 2019|work=The Buffalo News |access-date=July 25, 2019}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2018-11-20/inside-elon-musk-s-forgotten-gigafactory-2-in-buffalo |title=Inside Elon Musk's forgotten Gigafactory in Buffalo |last1=Carr |first1=Austin |last2=Eckhouse |first2=Brian |website=Bloomberg Businessweek |date=November 20, 2018 |access-date=July 25, 2019}}{{Cite web|date=April 30, 2020|title=Tesla will seek one-year break on job commitments|url=https://www.wivb.com/news/tesla-will-seek-one-year-break-on-job-commitments/|access-date=August 19, 2020|website=News 4 Buffalo|language=en-US}} The New York state comptroller released a "scathing" audit of the project, concluding that it presented many red flags, lacked basic due diligence, and produced only 54 cents in economic benefits for every $1 spent by the state (compared to the benchmark set for these types of projects of $30 in economic benefits for every $1 spent).{{Cite web|date=August 21, 2020|title=Scathing audit of high-tech projects slams ESD for lack of due diligence on Tesla at RiverBend|url=https://www.wivb.com/news/local-news/buffalo/scathing-audit-of-high-tech-projects-slams-esd-for-lack-of-due-diligence-on-tesla-at-riverbend/|access-date=August 21, 2020|website=News 4 Buffalo|language=en-US}} ==== Short sellers ==== As of January 15, 2020, Tesla stock was the most-[[Short (finance)|shorted]] in U.S. equity markets. Over 20% of its stock was shorted at that time, with many shorters losing large amounts of money as the stock price climbed much higher later in the year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/01/16/796328145/electric-burn-those-who-bet-against-elon-musk-and-tesla-are-paying-a-big-price|title=Electric Burn: Those Who Bet Against Elon Musk And Tesla Are Paying A Big Price|website=NPR.org}} [[TSLAQ]] is an informal and largely anonymous group of Tesla shorters and critics, mainly organized online. ==== Worker safety and rights ==== According to former employees at Tesla's Fremont factory, Tesla has systematically denied medical care to injured workers, forced injured workers to return to the production line without relief, and insisted that seriously injured workers be sent to the emergency room in a [[Lyft]] rather than call 911.{{Cite web|title=Inside Tesla's factory, a medical clinic designed to ignore injured workers|url=https://www.revealnews.org/article/inside-teslas-factory-a-medical-clinic-designed-to-ignore-injured-workers/|website=Reveal|language=en|access-date=May 15, 2020}} An investigation by [[Reveal (podcast)|Reveal]] found that Tesla "failed to report some of its serious injuries on legally mandated reports, making the company's injury numbers look better than they actually are."{{Cite web|title=Tesla says its factory is safer. But it left injuries off the books|url=https://www.revealnews.org/article/tesla-says-its-factory-is-safer-but-it-left-injuries-off-the-books/|website=Reveal|language=en|access-date=May 15, 2020}} Their factory injury rates are worse than the industry average, despite Musk claiming otherwise.{{Cite web|title=Tesla makes the safest cars in the world & our factory injury rate is better than industry avg & tracking to be better than any auto plant in North America. We care deeply about safety at a fundamental level.|url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1261106189258993665|last=Musk|first=Elon|date=May 14, 2020|website=@elonmusk|language=en|access-date=May 15, 2020}} From 2014 to 2018, Tesla's Fremont factory had three times as many [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] (OSHA) violations as the ten largest U.S. auto plants combined.{{Cite web|title=Tesla Had 3 Times as Many OSHA Violations as the 10 Largest US Plants Combined|url=https://www.thedrive.com/news/26727/tesla-had-3-times-as-many-osha-violations-as-the-10-largest-us-plants-combined|last=Stumpf|first=Rob|website=The Drive|access-date=May 15, 2020}} == Vehicle product issues == Tesla earned the worst score among the 32 major vehicle brands in J.D. Power's 2020 Initial Quality Study due to various problems reported by owners.[https://eu.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2020/06/24/jd-power-iqs-tesla-electric-vehicles-2020/3249943001/ J.D. Power rates Tesla electric vehicles as lowest quality auto brand in 2020 study], [[USA Today]], June 24, 2020 The first units for each new Tesla model revealed design and manufacturing flaws, including the Model S and the Model X.{{cite web |url=http://www.consumerreports.org/car-reliability/car-reliability-survey-2016/ |title=Consumer Reports Car Reliability Survey 2016 |magazine=[[Consumer Reports]] |date=October 24, 2016 |access-date=October 24, 2016 |quote=When a car model is brand new or "completely redesigned," that can mean new parts, new systems—and new problems.}}{{cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2016/10/26/tesla-model-x-92-reduction-issue/ |title=Tesla says it reduced Model X issues by 92% amid criticism from Consumer Reports |date=October 26, 2016 |first=Jameson |last=Dow |website=Electrek |access-date=October 26, 2016}} As the Tesla vehicle fleet grew, the number of service centers resulted in waiting periods for some owners.{{cite web |url=http://www.thecountrycaller.com/38757-tesla-motors-service-delays-have-little-or-no-effect-on-the-brand/ |title=Tesla Motors Service Delays Have Little Or No Effect On The Brand |work=The Country Caller |date=November 17, 2016 |access-date=November 21, 2016 |quote=Despite such poor servicing of vehicles, Blue Book's Karl Brauer believes that there has not been a big effect on the Tesla brand as early owners are not completely dependent on their Model S sedans and Model X SUVs. Dunne Automotive President, Michael Dunne, believes that the owners are well aware of such issues before buying a Tesla car as they know "they are part of this experience of the first breakthrough electric vehicles." |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161122071618/http://www.thecountrycaller.com/38757-tesla-motors-service-delays-have-little-or-no-effect-on-the-brand/ |archive-date=November 22, 2016}} Automotive research company [[Kelley Blue Book]] view the service delays as insignificant, as owners accept the challenges of servicing a new type of car. Other issues with vehicles included recalls, crashes and fires, delays, and software hacking. === Recalls === {{As of|2018|03}}, Tesla had issued two [[product recall]]s for the [[Tesla Roadster (2008)#Recalls|Roadster]], six for the [[Tesla Model S|Model S]] and two for the [[Tesla Model X#Recalls|Model X]].{{cite news |url=http://fortune.com/2016/04/11/tesla-recalls-2700-model-x-cars-for-seat-problem/ |title=Tesla Recalls 2,700 Model X Cars for Seat Problem |first=Katie |last=Fehrenbacher |magazine=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=April 11, 2016 |access-date=April 12, 2016}} On April 20, 2017, Tesla issued a worldwide recall of 53,000 (~70%) of the 76,000 vehicles it sold in 2016 due to faulty parking brakes which could become stuck and "prevent the vehicles from moving".{{cite news |title=Tesla's real problem isn't that its cars are expensive. It's that they're unreliable. |url=https://www.vox.com/2016/6/9/11880450/tesla-doomed |first=Timothy B. |last=Lee |website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |date=June 10, 2016 |access-date=April 21, 2017}}{{cite news |title=Tesla is recalling most of the cars it sold in 2016 |url=https://www.vox.com/new-money/2017/4/20/15374592/tesla-recall-53000-cars |first=Timothy B. |last=Lee |website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |date=April 20, 2017 |access-date=April 21, 2017}} On March 29, 2018, Tesla issued a worldwide recall of 123,000 Model S cars built before April 2016 due to [[corrosion]]-susceptible [[power steering]] bolts, which could fail and require the driver to use "increased force" to control the vehicle.{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/29/tesla-recalls-123000-model-s-cars-over-potential-power-steering-failure-reports.html |title=Tesla voluntarily recalls 123,000 Model S cars over faulty steering component |last=Wang |first=Christine |date=March 29, 2018 |work=CNBC|access-date=March 31, 2018}} In June 2016, the [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration|NHTSA]] announced that it was reviewing reports of suspension problems in Tesla Model S sedans.{{Cite news|date=June 9, 2016|title=U.S. reviewing suspension complaints in Tesla Model S cars|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-safety-idUSKCN0YV2DL|access-date=July 6, 2020}} The NHTSA also said they were aware that Tesla had entered into a "troublesome" non-disclosure agreement with one Model S owner regarding the suspension issue.{{Cite web|last=Niedermeyer|first=Edward|date=June 8, 2016|title=Tesla Suspension Breakage: It's Not The Crime, It's The Coverup|url=https://dailykanban.com/2016/06/08/tesla-suspension-breakage-not-crime-coverup/|access-date=July 6, 2020|website=DailyKanban|language=en-US}} Journalist and [[Ludicrous: The Unvarnished Story of Tesla Motors|author]] Ed Niedermeyer called this type of agreement "unheard of in the auto industry", and noted that a policy of demanding non-disclosure agreements for "goodwill" repairs would limit the number of defects Tesla owners reported to the NHTSA. Cases of the "whompy wheel" phenomenon, which also included Model X and the occasional Model 3 cars,{{Cite web|last=Lopez|first=Linette|title='Aladdin' star says a defect in his Tesla Model 3 led to his car wreck, and it comes from a problem area the company has known about for years|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/aladdin-stars-problem-with-tesla-known-as-whompy-wheels-2019-6|access-date=October 26, 2020|website=Business Insider}} have been documented through 2020.{{Cite web|last=Skwarczek|first=Matthew|date=May 28, 2020|title=Tesla Owners Shouldn't Be OK With Their Cars' Quality Issues|url=https://www.motorbiscuit.com/tesla-owners-shouldnt-be-ok-with-their-cars-quality-issues/|access-date=October 26, 2020|website=MotorBiscuit|language=en-US}} In October 2020, Tesla initiated a recall of nearly 50,000 Model X and Y vehicles throughout China{{Cite web|last=Kolodny|first=Lora|date=October 23, 2020|title=Tesla recalls nearly 50,000 Model S and X cars in China over faulty suspension|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/23/tesla-recalls-model-s/x-cars-in-china-over-faulty-suspension.html|access-date=October 26, 2020|website=CNBC|language=en}} and in November the NHTSA announced it had "opened an investigation into about 115,0000 Tesla vehicles over front suspension safety issues," citing 2015 - 2017 Model S and 2016 - 2017 Model X vehicles.{{Cite web|date=November 27, 2020|title=U.S. agency opens probe into 115,000 Tesla vehicles over suspension issue|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/27/us-agency-opens-probe-into-115000-tesla-vehicles-over-suspension-issue.html|access-date=December 9, 2020|website=CNBC|language=en}} In January 2021, NHTSA again asked for the recall of 158,000 vehicles (Model S vehicles built from 2012 to 2018 and Model X vehicles built between 2016 and 2018) over touchscreen failures that could possibly affect the rear-view camera, safety systems, Autopilot and other functions.{{Cite web|last=Ewing|first=Steven|title=Tesla asked to recall Model S, Model X over touchscreen failures|url=https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/tesla-model-s-model-x-touchscreen-recall/|access-date=2021-01-15|website=Roadshow|language=en}}{{Cite web|title=Tesla recalls 158,000 Model S and Model X vehicles – report {{!}} CarAdvice|url=https://www.caradvice.com.au/916000/tesla-recalls-158000-model-s-and-model-x-vehicles-report/|access-date=2021-01-15|website=CarAdvice.com|language=en}} === Crashes and fires === {{See also|Plug-in electric vehicle fire incidents#Tesla|Tesla Autopilot#Serious crashes}} Tesla vehicles have been involved in a number of controversial fires and crashes. Some of these crashes involve the use of the Autopilot driver assistance system. In 2013, a Model S caught fire after the vehicle hit metal debris on a highway in [[Kent, Washington]]. Tesla confirmed the fire began in the battery pack and was caused by the impact of an object.{{cite news |url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/10/02/highway-fire-of-tesla-model-s-included-its-lithium-battery/ |title=Tesla Says Car Fire Started in Battery |first=Christopher |last=Jensen |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 2, 2013 |access-date=October 7, 2013}} As a result of this and other incidents, Tesla announced its decision to extend its current vehicle warranty to cover fire damage.{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1088588_tesla-fires-nhtsa-will-probe-warranty-to-cover-fire-damage-ride-height-tweak |title=Tesla Fires: NHTSA Will Probe, Warranty To Cover Fire Damage, Ride-Height Tweak |first=John |last=Voelcker |website=Green Car Reports |date=November 19, 2013 |access-date=November 24, 2013}} On March 28, 2014, the [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA) announced that it had closed the investigation into whether the Model S was prone to catch fire, after the automaker said it would provide more protection to its battery packs.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/29/business/safety-agency-ends-investigation-of-tesla-fires.html |title=Federal Safety Agency Ends Its Investigation of Tesla Fires |first=Danielle |last=Ivory |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 28, 2014 |access-date=March 31, 2014}} All Model S cars manufactured after March 6, 2014, have had the {{convert|0.25|inch|adj=on}} aluminum shield over the battery pack replaced with a new three-layer shield.{{cite web |last=George |first=Patrick |title=The Tesla Model S: Now With Road Debris-Crushing Titanium! |url=http://jalopnik.com/the-tesla-model-s-now-with-road-debris-crushing-titani-1553544362 |website=[[Jalopnik]] |access-date=March 31, 2014 |date=March 28, 2014}} A Model S driver died in a collision with a tractor-trailer in 2016, while the vehicle was in Autopilot mode. The driver is believed to be the first person to have died in a Tesla vehicle in Autopilot.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/01/business/self-driving-tesla-fatal-crash-investigation.html |title=Self-Driving Tesla Was Involved in Fatal Crash, U.S. Says |first1=Bill |last1=Vlasic |first2=Neal E. |last2=Boudette |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 30, 2016 |access-date=July 1, 2016}}{{cite web |url=https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/HWY16FH018-preliminary.aspx |title=Preliminary Report, Highway HWY16FH018 |publisher=[[NTSB]] |date=July 26, 2016 |access-date=August 31, 2016}} The NHTSA investigated the accident but found no safety-related defect trend.{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/2017/01/probing-teslas-deadly-crash-feds-say-yay-self-driving/ |title=After Probing Tesla's Deadly Crash, Feds Say Yay to Self-Driving |magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |location=US |first=Jack |last=Steware |date=January 20, 2017 |access-date=April 17, 2017}} In March 2018, an Apple engineer was killed in a crash in a Tesla Model X. Investigators say that the driver of the vehicle had his car in ‘self-driving’ mode and was using his phone to play games when the vehicle collided with the barrier in the middle of the freeway. Through investigation, the National Transportation Safety Board found that the Tesla malfunctioned due to the system being confused by an exit on the freeway.{{cite web |title=Apple engineer killed in Tesla SUV crash on Silicon Valley freeway was playing videogame: NTSB |url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/apple-engineer-killed-in-tesla-suv-crash-on-silicon-valley-freeway-was-playing-videogame-ntsb-2020-02-25 |website=Market Watch |publisher=Market Watch |access-date=April 29, 2020}} === Delays === Tesla has been criticized for repeatedly over-promising and under-delivering. Delivery dates for new vehicles and new vehicle features slipped on the Roadster, Model S, Model X and Model 3. Advanced technologies like the prospect of a large network of [[solar-power]]ed supercharger stations (first installation was in 2012; only a few were solar-powered as of mid 2019){{Cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2019/07/18/tesla-v3-supercharger-station-las-vegas-solar-power-battery/|title=Tesla opens new V3 Supercharger with solar and battery - looks like EV charging station of the future|last=Lambert|first=Fred|date=July 18, 2019|website=Electrek|language=en-US|access-date=February 23, 2020}} also lagged projections.{{cite news |last1=Lavrinc |first1=Damon |title=What Will Tesla And Elon Musk Over Promise Next? |url=http://jalopnik.com/what-will-tesla-and-elon-musk-over-promise-next-1672402636 |access-date=December 18, 2014 |website=[[Jalopnik]] |date=December 17, 2014}} In early October 2017, Musk had predicted that Model 3 production would be up to 5,000 units per week by December.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/innovations/wp/2017/10/02/we-understand-what-needs-to-be-fixed-tesla-says-after-bungling-model-3-production-goals/ |title='We understand what needs to be fixed,' Tesla says after missing Model 3 production goals |first=Peter |last=Holley |date=October 2, 2017 |access-date=November 5, 2017 |via=Washington Post}} A month later, he revised that target to "sometime in March" 2018 due in part to difficulties with robots on the assembly line, but primarily due to problems with the battery module.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/innovations/wp/2017/11/03/sleepless-nights-broken-robots-and-mounting-pressure-musk-offers-rare-glimpse-inside-teslas-production-hell |title=Analysis – Sleepless nights, broken robots and mounting pressure: Musk offers rare glimpse inside Tesla's 'production hell'|last=Holley|first=Peter |date=November 3, 2017 |website=WashingtonPost.com |access-date=November 6, 2017}} An analyst with Cowan and Company, a public relations firm, made this comment: "Elon Musk needs to stop over promising and under delivering".{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-results-reaction/tesla-must-stop-overpromising-could-need-more-finance-analysts-idUSKBN1D21A3 |title=Tesla must stop overpromising, could need more finance: analysts |date=November 2, 2017 |access-date=November 6, 2017 |via=Reuters}} On September 24, 2018, Musk revealed on [[Twitter]] that Tesla will be building its own car carriers as the company is facing challenges due to logistics. Tesla is running into an acute shortage of car carrier trailers leading to a delay in the delivery.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-musk/tesla-is-making-its-own-car-carriers-idUSKCN1M42HG?il=0 |title=Tesla is making its own car carriers |work=Reuters |access-date=September 25, 2018}} In mid-November, with end-of-year buyer tax credits expiring in a little more than six weeks, Musk announced that the company was aggressively ramping up delivery capabilities with trucking contracts and even outright purchase of some trucking firms to deliver as many cars as possible before the deadline.{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/11/15/tesla-acquires-trucking-companies-to-squeeze-in-more-deliveries-before-dec-31/|title=Tesla acquires trucking companies to squeeze in more deliveries before Dec. 31|work=TechCrunch|access-date=November 16, 2018|language=en-US}} === Hacking === In August 2015, two researchers said they were able to take control of a Tesla Model S by hacking into the car's entertainment system.{{cite news |url=https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-hy-tesla-hack-20150806-story.html |title=Researchers hack a Tesla Model S, bring car to stop |first=Samantha |last=Masunaga |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=August 6, 2015 |access-date=August 10, 2015}} The hack required the researchers to physically access the car.{{cite web |last1=Mahaffey |first1=Kevin |title=The |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/08/researchers-hacked-model-s-teslas-already/ |title=Tesla patches Model S after researchers hack car's software |first=Fred |last=O'Connor |magazine=[[Wired They were able to compromise the automotive networking bus ([[CAN bus]]) when the vehicle's web browser was used while the vehicle was connected to a malicious Wi-Fi hotspot.{{cite web |url=http://keenlab.tencent.com/en/2016/09/19/Keen-Security-Lab-of-Tencent-Car-Hacking-Research-Remote-Attack-to-Tesla-Cars/ |title=Car Hacking Research: Remote Attack Tesla Motors|access-date=September 21, 2016}} This was the first case of a remote control exploit demonstrated on a Tesla. The vulnerability was disclosed to Tesla under their [[bug bounty program]]{{cite web |title=Product Security {{!}} Tesla |url=https://www.tesla.com/en_GB/about/security?redirect=no |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190225222341/https://www.tesla.com/en_GB/about/security |archive-date=February 25, 2019 |website=tesla.com |url-status=live}} and patched within 10 days, before the exploit was made public.{{cite web |url=https://electrek.co/2016/09/20/first-tesla-model-s-remotely-controlled-hackers-tesla-pushed-a-fix/ |title=First Tesla Model S remotely controlled by hackers, Tesla already pushed a fix |last=Lambert |first=Fred |date=September 20, 2016 |website=Electrek |access-date=September 21, 2016}} Tencent also hacked the doors of a Model X in 2017.{{cite magazine |url=http://fortune.com/2017/07/28/tesla-model-x-tencent/ |title=This Tesla Investor's Tech Team Just Hacked the Model X – Again |magazine=Fortune |date=July 28, 2017 |access-date=October 15, 2017}} In January 2018, security researchers informed Tesla that an [[Amazon Web Services]] account of theirs could be accessed directly from the Internet and that the account had been exploited for [[cryptocurrency]] mining. Tesla responded by securing the compromised system, rewarding the security researchers financially via their bug bounty program, and stating that the compromise did not violate customer privacy, nor vehicle safety or security.{{cite news |url=http://fortune.com/2018/02/20/tesla-hack-amazon-cloud-cryptocurrency-mining/ |title=Tesla Hackers Hijacked Amazon Cloud Account to Mine Cryptocurrency |website=fortune.com |first=Robert |last=Hackett |date=February 20, 2018 |access-date=February 21, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2018/02/20/tesla-cloud-hijacked-hackers-mine-cryptocurrencies/ |title=Tesla's cloud was 'hijacked' by hackers to mine cryptocurrencies |website=electrek.co |first=Fred |last=Lambert |date=February 20, 2018 |access-date=February 21, 2018}} In 2019, Tesla awarded a car and $375,000 to [[White hat (computer security)|ethical hackers]] during a [[Pwn2Own]] Model 3 |url=https://www.techtimes.com/articles/240177/20190324/hackers-who-cracked-tesla-model-3-security-in-competition-win-electric-car-and-375k.htm |website=Tech Times |language=en |date=March 24, 2019}} The company does not report sales monthly.{{cite web |url=http://insideevs.com/tesla-ceo-elon-musk-heres-dont-report-monthly-sales-figures/ |title=Tesla CEO Elon Musk: Here's Why We Don't Report Monthly Sales Figures |date=2014 |access-date=September 24, 2016}} On March 9, 2020, the company produced its 1 millionth electric car, becoming the first [[auto manufacturer]] to achieve such a milestone.{{Cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2020/03/09/tesla-produces-1000000th-electric-car/|title=Tesla produces its 1 millionth electric car|last=Lambert|first=Fred|date=March 10, 2020|website=Electrek|language=en-US|access-date=March 28, 2020}} ===Dealership disputes in the United States=== {{Main|Tesla US dealership disputes}} [[File:Tesla store, Austin, Texas 01.jpg|thumb|Tesla gallery in [[Austin, Texas]] ]] Tesla operates stores and galleries—usually located in shopping malls—in many U.S. states. However, customers buy vehicles only from the Tesla website.{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/11/20/tesla-battles-auto-dealers-direct-sales-consumers/3f1xBFN21xH8QqQc3jijTP/story.html |title=Tesla battles auto dealers on direct sales to consumers |newspaper=Boston Globe |first=Callum |last=Borchers |date=November 20, 2013}} The stores serve as showrooms that allow people to learn about the company and its vehicles. Some galleries are located in states with restrictive dealer protection laws that prohibit discussing prices or financing, or providing test drives, as well as other restrictions. Forty-eight states have laws that limit or ban manufacturers from selling vehicles directly to consumers,{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-06-20/news/ct-oped-0620-chapman-20130620_1_tesla-motors-car-dealers-car-costs |work=Chicago Tribune |first=Steve |last=Chapman |title=Car buyers get hijacked |date=June 20, 2013 |access-date=April 12, 2015}} and although Tesla has no independent dealerships, dealership associations in multiple states have filed lawsuits over Tesla's sales practices. In response, Tesla has lobbied in several states for the right to sell cars. Countries other than United States do not protect dealers.{{Cite web|last=McCorvey|first=J. J.|date=August 8, 2016|title=Road Rules: How Tesla Plans to Change The Way We Buy Cars|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3062100/road-rules-how-tesla-plans-to-change-the-way-we-buy-cars|access-date=September 2, 2020|website=Fast Company|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|date=February 5, 2002|title=Another way to sell cars|work=The Economist|url=https://www.economist.com/unknown/2002/02/05/another-way-to-sell-cars|access-date=September 2, 2020|issn=0013-0613}}{{Cite web|last=KPMG|date=July 16, 2018|title=Will this be the end of car dealerships as we know it?|url=https://advisory.kpmg.us/articles/2018/will-this-be-the-end-of-car-dealerships-as-we-know-them.html}} The [[Federal Trade Commission]] recommends allowing direct manufacturer sales,{{cite web |url=https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/blogs/competition-matters/2015/05/direct-consumer-auto-sales-its-not-just-about-tesla |title=Direct-to-consumer auto sales: It's not just about Tesla |access-date=July 16, 2015|date=May 11, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/news/1098273_can-the-ftc-persuade-michigan-other-states-to-open-their-doors-to-tesla |title=Can The FTC Persuade Michigan & Other States To Open Their Doors To Tesla? |author=Richard Read |work=The Car Connection |access-date=July 16, 2015}} which government analysts believe would save consumers 8% in average vehicle price.{{cite web |url=https://www.justice.gov/atr/public/eag/246374.htm |title=Economic Effects Of State Bans On Direct Manufacturer Sales To Car Buyers |first=Gerald R. |last=Bodisch |publisher=Department of Justice |location=US |date=May 2009 |access-date=July 9, 2019}} == Finances == [[File:Tesla Financial Performance.svg|thumb|Financial performance]] For the fiscal year 2019, Tesla reported losses of US$862 million, with an annual revenue of US$24.578 billion, an increase of 14.5% over the previous fiscal cycle.
